reviews.author: Alexwu
reviews.title: 靚grade course 唔洗擔心
reviews.comment_content:
Digital Economy (I, II, III)
E-commerce (I, II, III, IV)
Online Platform (I, II, III)
Business Analytics (I, II)
Big Data (I, II)

You have to finish a project with your teammate (you can do it with your fds) about e-commerce. Professor requires you to identify the difficulties of your selected e-commerce and propose some suggestions. The weird part is that the suggestions could have nothing to do with IS, so just be creative and make sure it is valid and workable. At the end of the day, I didn't know what I was doing. lol

Basically easy things that we already know but introduced in a more systematic way with theory.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The course is boring, so not many people paid attention in class. She tried to make interaction with students but got no responses, which was embarrassing.
However, we could tell that she is an expert in IS area. And, she explained the concept quite clearly.
reviews.comment_grading:
Participation 15%
Labs 15%
Research Project 20%
Midterm Exam 25%
Final Exam 25%

Participation: I think I got full marks.
Labs: Full marks
Research Project: Unknown
Midterm Exam: 45/50 (mean 39)
Final: unknown but I think I did well

Grade: A+
reviews.comment_workload:
Acceptable workload. The exam is not cumulative, which means that even though you mess up on the mid-term, you could still chase it.
Lab attendance is not a must, but you have to make sure you finish the quiz every week right after the lab session.
For the group project, you have to prepare a 15mins presentation and a maximum 12 pages report (double spacing). The workload wasn't huge if you chose the right topic and groupmates.
Professor will randomly do IPRS for attendance, dont skip the lecture if you do care about the parti.
Also, attending the talks during the industrial week also counts towards the parti marks.

reviews.author: jistewoo
reviews.title: Pretty good grade course
reviews.comment_content:
It is an introductory course in Information Systems. The content is quite boring and it is not closely related to IS. The syllabus will be similar to other reviews

- Digital Economy
- E-commerce
- Software&Hardware
- Database (SQL)
- Business Analysis
- Big Data
reviews.comment_teaching: It is quite boring during the lectures because I usually take a seat at the back. You can skip all the lessons if you want because most of the content can be found on the PowerPoint slides. Don't miss the lecture on group forming. It is always important to find some good teammates by yourself in the lecture. :)
reviews.comment_grading:
Not bad at all. I want to study in IS as my major (Want to acquire the finance major at first but the grade is not satisfactory at the end) There are one midterm, one group presentations and final exam.

Participation (15%):
There will be some iprs open-ended questions in random lessons and you will need to attend industrial talks and give presentation feedbacks to gain participation points.

Labs (15%):
Topics included SQL, VBA , website building and some coding. There will have a lab quiz every week (unlimited attempts) to get full credit. 10% will be allocated to the final exam.

Research project (20%) : you will need to write a report and give a group presentation on a company based on the IS knowledge that has been taught in the lesson. Professor Xu will challenge you with some questions. Grades did not release at the end but I think I did a bad job given that we cannot answer the questions in the Q and A and the content is pretty vague and did not give a thorough solution on the company. I also got some teammates that are free-riding so make sure to find the teammates by yourself :)

Midterm covered the digital economy and e-commerce. Labs materials will not be covered.
mid-term (25%): 33.5/50 (mean: 39/50) (below 1.5sd)

Final (25%) will cover online platforms and business analytics and big data. Labs materials will be covered

I studied very hard for the final exam but the grades did not release. I guess I got a pretty good score. There will be two papers in the final exam. One is the final and the other is the lab.

Final grade: B
I expect a C-range because I did poorly in the midterm and I think it is not satisfactory in the research project but still got a B in the end. I am so happy that I can acquire IS major at the end.
reviews.comment_workload:
Very light workload

Not required to attend lectures. Just study the slides and you can get a pretty good grade.

Lab materials are also not difficult if you study the notes. It will not take you a lot of time.

reviews.author: clavc
reviews.title: Interesting course
reviews.comment_content: I think content wise the course is very good. The topics are pretty interesting.
reviews.comment_teaching: I can see she's really passionate with the topics, even though she mostly read from the PPT. And she's really willing to help (just ask her for consultation if you ever needed to) for the group project.
reviews.comment_grading:
Fair grading

I get mean for midterm, missed one (or two lol) in class activities, kinda messed up my finals, and I guessed a pretty decent score for my group project.
The midterm and final are not hard, so very high mean, if you want to guarantee A-range, I think it's very important to aced your group project.

Final score B.
reviews.comment_workload:
Adequate workload.

Need to put effort for the group project as she can be really harsh and will really help in the q&a if you really understand your solutions.
For the midterm and final, revising her PPT is enough. And make sure to attend industry talks for the participation grade.

reviews.author: zmalqp
reviews.comment_content:
Course Description
In virtually every industry and every firm, information technology (IT) is driving change, creating opportunities and challenges. Leaders who don’t understand the fundamentals of information systems (IS) will be at a strategic disadvantage. IS have moved beyond the automation of back office functions, into the foreground of business strategy. IS play critical roles in competitive positioning and business process design.
This course provides broad coverage of technology concepts and social and economic trends underlying current and future developments in IT, and fundamental principles for the effective use of computer-based IS in businesses and other organizations. There will be a special emphasis on the digital economy, e-commerce, and business analytics. Other topics include: hardware/software, networking, the Internet, database, security, and social media. In additional to the fundamental conceptual and propositions in the IS area, a number of business applications and cases will be discussed. (Honestly I still cannot understand why the school made this course. useless hahahha)
reviews.comment_teaching: class is boarig. After few weeks, seat in the back row and watch what your classmates are doing.  You will find out 95percent of them doing their own things lol. Tutorial teaching is even worse. Just self study and do the quiz. As the lab quiz is unlimited trial, you will able to get full mark.
reviews.comment_grading: worse than expected. I did quite good on midterm (1.x sd above) and  the group projects (I think). Full attendance and I think average on final exam. I actually expected A range but ended up in B range.
reviews.comment_workload:
Participation, Labs, Research Project, Midterm Exam, Final Exam
Seems a lot but quite manageable as the contents are not difficult

1) Digital Economy

3) Online Platform

One of the most boring professors I've ever met. She only "read" from her PowerPoint.
Sometime she would play some videos. The funniest thing is you can't open these videos from the lecture notes (the lectures notes are in pdf form), but she tested some of the video content in the midterm :)
reviews.comment_grading:
You would get a good grade if you study hard. Most of the thing is only about memorising. (Especially for the lab content)
I think I screwed up my presentation, but still get an A+ in the final score

Most of the workload for the lecture is the group project. Go find a good partner and you will be good.

Lab:
Quiz every week. Unlimited attempts are allowed. Just trial and error.

reviews.author: catisking
reviews.title: Surprising grading
reviews.comment_content: The content can take others as a reference. Just some basic isom knowledge. Nothing hard at all.
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof Yin's teaching is very interactive. There is a lot of Q&A sessions during lectures and many students keep raising their hands. He walks around the classroom to give everyone a try which is pretty fair. He has an accent but it can be well understood.
reviews.comment_grading:
Discussion: 15/15
Lab: 12/15
Group Project 18/20
Mid-term Exam: 20.25/25
Final Exam: 21.25/25

My total score is above the mean nearly 1 sd. But it turns out to be A range. So it is quite out of my surprise.
reviews.comment_workload: No workload at all. Only need to hand in a group project (about developing e-commerce in HK) and we can choose our own groupmates. Both mid-term and final are open-book. There are mc and short questions in the mid-term but there are only short questions in the final. You don't have to memorize anything except for the lab final. But make sure you jot down what he mentions during the Q&A session. Those will be tested in exams.

reviews.author: Ireneee
reviews.title: Surprisingly good grade
reviews.comment_content:
Lecture:
Digital economy, e-commerce, social media, technical foundations, big data, business analytics and decision makings, (business, accounting and finance), technology-enabled business trends.

Lab:
Web analytics, business analytics using Microsoft Excel, advanced business analytics, database using Microsoft Access, big data analytics

These are taught and tested separately, two lectures and one lab per week. There is also a week dedicated to industry talk. I like the lab content way more than lecture content.
reviews.comment_teaching: XU Hong answers questions raised by us in detail and explains the concept quite clearly. Her PPTs are good enough to prepare for exams.
reviews.comment_grading:
Participation (15%): Attend industry week talks (2 out of 3) + comments on others’ presentations, and these should be fairly easy to complete.

Labs (15%): Each lab comes with a quiz and it is quite easy to obtain full marks with unlimited attempts. The time for final exam is a bit tense but still fair if you are familiar with the content. One summary sheet was provided.

Research Project (20%): A group work including proposal, presentation and report. The marks for the latter two were not revealed. Quite an interesting experience to identify a problem in existing e-commerce and provide a solution for it.

Midterm (25%): MCQs with some short answer questions. MCQs a little tricky to me but I nailed the short answer questions, as they were quite straightforward and easy to prepare for.

Final (25%): Only a few MCQs with some more short answer questions compared to midterm. Not as tricky but I thought I did probably around the mean.

My final grade is A+, in which I absolutely did not expect even A range. My midterm is slightly above mean but probably I did great on lab and better than expected for finals. GREAT thanks to professor and TAs.
reviews.comment_workload:
Very light workload in general.

Great thanks to my group mates, we had no free-riders, so the workload of group project was very manageable.

Just attend the industry talk and write comments for participation and go through all the slides for exams.

reviews.author: ebi
reviews.title: Good Professor
reviews.comment_content: Just memorizing all the stuff. The contents are not too complicated, and many of them are common sense. Memorizing it is not too difficult.
reviews.comment_teaching: Good professor. He tries to explain everything clearly. Though he is simply reading his slides throughout the course. His slides are so helpful so I don't mind him reading them. TBH I think he is really a good professor~
reviews.comment_grading:
Everyone get high marks.
I did poorly in mt (lower than mean a lot), but final above mean.
Presentation fair.

Got a B.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is quite light but you have to memorize the contents. The lab is easy.

This course also has lab sessions, TBH lab sessions are somewhat more useful compared to the course, but the labs also did not cover too much.

Even though he might try to explain, the only thing he did was to parapharase the concepts,so I sometimes wondered whether I was taking a language course or business course.
reviews.comment_grading: If you received education from crammer schools before, then youu will like this course and may get good grade. I will not judge his grading as I also did not pay full effort.
reviews.comment_workload: Not so heavy workload. Just 2 exams and a project in his lecture. Don't have to spend much extra time except for preparing those exams and project. But the porject is just a waste of time if your teammates sucks. If you really want to major in IS just don't come to his course.

reviews.author: kariri
reviews.title: Not Bad, light workload generally
reviews.comment_content:
Give nice insights into information systems, I think the prof did a good job explaining the introductory concepts, divided into four main sections Digital Economy, E-commerce, Digital platform, and Big data.
However, the labs seem completely related to the lectures talking about excel VBA. Wasn't difficult but let's just say not very well structured...
reviews.comment_teaching:
I like Professor Zhitao; his PPTs are great! Clear and concise, filled with images with keywords highlighted. If you don't pay much attention in class, you can still understand the concepts 100% without watching the recordings just reading the ppts. The midterm and finals are compatible with what's on the PPTs.
There's a participation grade of 15%; I would recommend sitting in the front rows of the class. He'll remember your face ( he walks around with a sheet of paper with everyone's name and photo printed on it, trust me he'll know). He also walks around with a microphone and randomly picks students to answer stuff. Don't need to worry too much the questions aren't hard and open-ended.  
I don't find his voice boring and he talks about examples, shows videos, and tells you to interact with peers to discuss before answering the qestion.
reviews.comment_grading:
Would've gotten a better grade if it were for the lab exams :/

But the finals and midterms aren't hard and open book.
reviews.comment_workload: Generally, a light workload and doesn't give homework or problem sets. Though there is a weekly lab quiz to be submitted in class. Only gets a bit heavy during the group project that's worth 20%, but you can pick your teammates, so no free riders. Presentation, and he doesn't like you to read from a script FYI.

reviews.author: CAJAY
reviews.comment_content:
same stuff as others said
Digital Economy
E-Commerce
Online Platforms
Business Analytics
Big Data Analytics
overall, just memorize all things on ppts.
reviews.comment_teaching: very nice teacher, teaching is not so boring, and will answer your email very quickly. happy to answer your questions and give recommandation to your proposal
reviews.comment_grading:
not yet graded, but probably quite good
midterm: mean 75.25; sd 14.74; median 78
reviews.comment_workload:
the group project is the biggest workload, needed to create a new mobile app and write business proposal plus doing presentation.
one midterm and one final, the content is not cumulative

reviews.author: SLCN
reviews.title: Good grade
reviews.comment_content:
Lecture 內容唔難，都係common sense嘢，唔需要coding或者複雜計算。

reviews.comment_teaching: Professor講嘢比較悶，有少少口音但唔會聽唔明，上堂基本上佢都係跟住powerpoint講，間唔中問一兩條問題，無class discussion 。
reviews.comment_grading:
-Participation 15%
    上堂iprs+聽兩個talk+寫presentation feedback form
-Labs 15%(5% canvas mc quiz+10% open book mc exam)
-Research Project 20%
-Midterm Exam 25% (closed book)
-Final Exam 25% (closed book) (non-cumulative)
只有midterm exam有release grade， research project無feedback無grade。佢d卷出得好簡單，同埋問概嘅只佔powerpoint好少內容，唔洗溫得好深入。Midterm+1.2sd，participation應該滿分，Project同Final 我覺得我一般，最後A，都幾靚grade。
reviews.comment_workload: 少，research project大家肯做就得。Lab只有上第一堂，其他都係睇note，因為TA真係照住份note讀。

reviews.author: xyzgabc
reviews.comment_content: The course was about some basic knowledge of Information Systems, it gives you brief introduction to IS with some topics including e-commerce, digital goods etc. The content is a bit boring and more like about common sense
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof did a pretty good teaching tho sometimes are a bit boring but she tried to give a lot of real life examples to elaborate on certain concepts or topics, like Amazon, eBay etc. She is also willing to answer students questions regarding on their projects, you can also book your consultation with he (usually many people stay behind after class)
reviews.comment_grading:
Participation 15% (no lecture attendance but there will be IPRS during lessons randomly so make sure you do not miss it, also industry workshops)
Labs 15% (lab weekly quizzes with unlimited attempts)
Research Project 20%
Midterm Exam 25%
Final Exam 25% (including lab exams)
I think final exam and project matters more than midterm
cuz I scored 42/50 in midterm (mean: 40.74 SD: 4.34)
Final exam& research project score not released (not reli transparent)
Final grade A (didn't expect could reach A range)
-for the research project groupmates matter (formed by your own) and also better ask prof for more questions or opinions
reviews.comment_workload:
Quite a lot
-Mid-term (closed book)
Project includes a progress report, final report and live presentation
-Final exam (including lab exams, closed book)
-Labs
- Industry workshops (count towards participation)

reviews.author: InezW
reviews.title: Common sense stuff and good grade
reviews.comment_content:
Lesson and Topics
1 Introduction
2 Digital Economy (I)
3 Digital Economy (II)
4 Digital Economy (III) (Due: Group List)
5 E-Commerce (I)
6 E-Commerce (II)
7 E-Commerce (III) (Due: Proposal)
8 E-Commerce (IV)
9 Midterm Review
10 Industry Exposure (Tentative)
11 Industrial talks
12 Midterm Exam
13 No Class: Chung Yeung Festival
14 Online Platform (I) (Due: Presentation Slots Choice)
15 Online Platform (II)
16 Online Platform (III)
17 Business Analytics (I)
18 Business Analytics (II)
19 Big Data Analytics (I)
20 Big Data Analytics (II)
21 Project Presentation (I)
22 Project Presentation (II)
23 Project Presentation (III)
24 Project Presentation (IV)
25 Emerging Technologies in IS
26 Final Exam Review (Due: Project Report)

Tutorials
Business Analytics using Microsoft Excel, Advanced Business Analytics and Database using Microsoft Access.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof is kind and knows what she is talking about. The discussion atmosphere is good in her lessons. Her slides are clear and explain major confusion about similar concepts.
For tutorials, ta just read and follow the lab guidelines. Easy to follow.
reviews.comment_grading:
The group stuff's scores and final exam scores were not released.
Online lab quizzes: everyone got full marks i guess.
Midterm: My score = mean
I thought it's going to be a B range grade, then turned out to be A-, really good grade.
Prof used IPRS and industrial talks to record attendance.
reviews.comment_workload:
Just group project proposal (full marked as long as the group submitted), group presentation, then group project report. One midterm and final exam.
There are some reading materials but those are just some industrial news and prof will go through them in class. They were tested in midterm.

For tutorials, Excel, Access and big data were covered, have weekly online quizzes (unlimited attempts and unlimited time allowance, around 5 mcqs or fill-in-the-blanks.) Tested in final exam separately.

reviews.author: A1111
reviews.comment_content: The course material is pretty is easy to understand which is an introductory course about information system.
reviews.comment_teaching: The prof explained it with lots of examples. As long as you go to the lecture, you'll understand the course content. The lab section is a bit difficult even if you attended all lab sections. Remember to ask your TA for your lab section. They are definitely helpful.
reviews.comment_grading: Not easy to get a good grade, please pay attention to your lab section.
reviews.comment_workload: It's pretty light workload, which are in-class disscussion, lab work and lab exam, midterm, final and group project.

reviews.author: GPASHIT
reviews.comment_content:
Digital Economy
1. Explain data, information, and information systems.  
2. Know the meaning of Moore’s law, Metcalf’s law and their implications.
3. Understand the implications of globalization.
4. Discuss the use of information systems in organizations.  
5. Describe the newer aspects of working in the digital world.  
6. Define ethics and describe the major ethical problems posed by the digital world.
Ecommerce
1. Describe the nature of e-business.  
2. Define the e-business value chain and disintermediation.  
3. Describe the basic e-business models.  
4. Examine the major online marketing methods.  
5. Discuss the major issues that are created by and affect e-business.

Social Media  
1. Describe the key component of social media.
2. Explain the 3 features of social media authoring.
3. Understand the meaning of Tagging.
4. Explain the differences between traditional and social media.


Technical Foundations
1. Identify the major components of hardware and networking technology.
2. Identify the different types of software.
3. Describe the process in software development.  
4. Discuss the trends in hardware and software, and the implications to businesses.
  ISOM 2010, Hong Xu
3
Big Data
1. Explain how organizations use data and information.  
2. Explain the basic concepts of data management (data creation, sharing, mining, reporting).
3. Define database management systems (DBMS) and describe their various functions.  
4. Data storage within and across organizations.  
5. Explain how the relational database model works.
6. Describe how databases are developed.  
7. Explain how organizations can use data warehousing and data mining for decision making.  
8. Describe advanced database models and when their use is appropriate.

Business Analytics and Decision Makings
1. Discuss the problems associated with management decision-making.  
2. Explain  the  specific  information  needs  of  managers  in  different  functional  areas  of  an  organization,  
including production, operations, marketing and sales, accounting, human resources and IT.
3. Explain the decision-making process.  
4. Explain  the  increasing  roles  and  responsibilities  of  accountants  as  user  and  owner  of  data  and  the  
corporate information system.
5. Describe decision support systems.  
6. Describe  the  opportunities  and  threats  to  corporate  information  system  including  capabilities  in  data  
treatment  and  analysis,  data  integrity,  system  security  and  issues  in  access  restriction,  and  business  
contingency/continuity.
7. Discuss the roles and trend of IT in business analytics and decision making

Business, Accounting and Finance
1. Formulate  appropriate  information  systems  strategies  to  support  implementation  of  business  and  
functional strategies.
2. Use the system development life cycle to plan, design, implement, and evaluate an IT system.
3. Describe the application of information technology to accounting systems and the generation, reporting,
internal control and attestation of accounting information.
4. Recognize and understand the roles of accountants in all stages of the system development life cycle:
systems analysis; systems design; systems implementation; and systems operation and maintenance.
5. Demonstrate  an  understanding  of  the  behavioral  issues  of  implementing  information  systems  in  
organizations.
6. Describe how change management can contribute to successful implementation of information systems.

Technology-Enabled Business Trends
1. Identify major tech-enabled trends in near future
2. Examine impact of tech-enabled trends on individuals, firms, and society
3. Discuss business opportunities of new technologies
reviews.comment_teaching:
A bit boring and dull, sleepy as the professor has a boring voice. Study her slides before MT or finals would be helpful.

Would say this course's workload is not big

reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor 個人好串 之前group project問佢意見嘅時候串嘅程度係max 同埋由於當時太多人係zoom所以串我地下次唔開zoom （但其實最後都係有開）同埋上得耐左就會覺得佢講嘅嘢令人地好眼瞓 有mixed mode就上zoom 啦 不過平時上堂會比好多info你上佢堂幾有用

而裏面嘅TA係廢嘅 聽都聽唔明 完全唔洗理佢 Lab都唔會計Attendence 唔好上啦
reviews.comment_grading:
開心到死居然呢個爛grade人生可以有leng grade :)

仲以為自己final exam衰左 因為佢出得勁tricky但又唔係真係好難 搞到自己好unsure個答案 Final exam有MC + LQ 最衰係close book 而lab session係全MC但open book 基本上copy曬啲code係張cheat sheet 就可以

Midterm較為簡單 但都係close book 但只要recite曬就可以

仲有個勁廢嘅部分就係lab talk x2 上到去都係掛機 去唔到就寫200字感想 吹水就得一定可以滿分

至於佢個participation marks 唔知佢點計 有時佢會有iprs 叫你做 真係唔知佢計唔計分 個人覺得冇lol

Group project自己分組 建議同friend一起讀同一個時間 冇freeride就冇事 format係搵間e-commerce講下 presentation + report

至於個lab係每個week撞幾次MC 容易滿分
Participation 15%
Labs 15%
Research Project 20%
Midterm Exam 25%
Final Exam 25%
Total 100%
reviews.comment_workload:
其實得midterm, final, group project 唔算好多嘢做 因為group project係第一個session就present左 所以相對上唔會同其他course嘅academic peak撞左 但之後仲有report所以好似吊住條尾咁

最煩嘅係LAB 嘅功課 每個禮拜都要做幾條MC 因為係無限次attempt所以只要有恆心就可以滿分

reviews.comment_teaching: Choosing Prof. XU Hong's class is probably the best decision I've ever made during the semester. Though some of the reviews said her class might be a little bit boring, I do think most of the content interests me a lot.
reviews.comment_grading: The grading is very good. I never expect to get an A+ because I only got the mean in the midterm, and I don't think I did exceptionally well in the final. To be honest, I don't know exactly why I got such a good grade, but I do think if so it must be my group project which boosted my grade up.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload's fair as long as your teammates are responsible. Only one big project throughout the whole semester.

reviews.author: imcat
reviews.title: 靚 Grade Xu Hong
reviews.comment_content: 呢個 course essentially 係你睇 tech news 嘅延伸版。最 value-adding 嘅我諗都係 collaborative filtering, market-basket analysis 嘅呢啲 business analytics 嘢。Don't expect very advanced stuff. 基本嘅 IS tools 就會喺 Lab 到有，Excel (Vlookup and other fundamental formulae 同埋 VBA)、Access (SQL 嘅入入入門版）。
reviews.comment_teaching: Lecture notes are very self-explanatory, just attend the lectures to get the participation points and make Prof feel less bored.
reviews.comment_grading:
Got A+:
Midterm MCQ: 27/30
Midterm Essay: 18/20
Midterm Total: Mean: 40.74; SD: 4.34
Final: Unknown
Project: Unknown

I think the project got me A+.
reviews.comment_workload:
Light. No ASM for lectures.
For Lab, just trial and error the quizzes as unlimited attempts.

Project is the only workload. Make sure you make your thing completely logical and no loopholes to be refuted. Storytelling skills matter. Put more effort into thinking about the structure of your presentation! Also, make sure you understand the rationale behind your recommendations completely to answer Prof's questions cuz Prof is very knowledgeable and can ask very insightful questions.

reviews.author: proffff
reviews.comment_content: Information systems (IS) is about managing the applications of IT to create business values. Topics include fundamental concepts of IS, e-commerce, digital and internet economy, web 2.0 and social networks, online advertising, personalization and privacy, digital rights management and piracy, business intelligence and decision-making, how organizations harness IS for innovative business strategies, and the socio-economic impact of IS on organizations and societies. The labs cover business problem-solving skills.
reviews.comment_teaching: Bad..She tried her best but still taught badly. And the ppt were quite concise I think
reviews.comment_grading: Bad..But my classmates said they got good grade, I just don't know why I got bad grade.
reviews.comment_workload: Extremely light

But he is also a strict person with solid rules and requirements

Fair Enough
Grades of group project are similar for each group, which is quite high
Some reading assignments are given, can easily get full marks if submit on time
These can eliminate the disadvantage of having a bad project teammate. The final grade basically depends on your sole marks of final and mid term exam
reviews.comment_workload:

Mainly Project work

reviews.comment_content:

The lab focuses more on the programming part.

Nice and funny teaching.
Explains concepts really well in an interesting way.
reviews.comment_grading:
A very small number of questions for mid and final.
Thus, hard to tell who is good and who is not.
reviews.comment_workload:
Very light.
Few article reading assignments.
One group project/presentation but gives enough time to prepare.

Lab-
A quiz after every session.
Can retake it multiple times until you get 100.

reviews.author: Beechenghiang
reviews.title: REAL GOOD GRADE COURSE!!!!!!!
reviews.comment_content:
Digital Economy
E-Commerce
Online Platforms
Industry Week
Business Analytics
Big Data Analytics
Emerging Technology: Blockchain

Just really basic stuff and brief concepts.
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof Lee just kept reading the slides directly and didn’t add anything new. But if you got any questions regarding the slides he will try to answer your questions.
reviews.comment_grading:
Class Participation 15%
Labs15%
Group Project20%
Midterm Exam20%
Final Exam30%

No score released for the final exam and the group project.
Also no idea on how the participation points was calculated but got an B+ at last.
I would say the grading is quite lenient cuz I only started looking through the lecture slides 2 days before the exam.
reviews.comment_workload: Quite heavy. You need to finish a group project proposal with 8 pages and you gonna memorise everything for the exam. Cuz he will cover some really detailed thingy that you never expected to be asked in the exam.

reviews.author: BreXuuuuuuu
reviews.comment_content:
covers basic content on digital technology, e commerce and business analytics.
I wouldn't say the content's very practical but it doesn't hurt to learn some theories on platform business, big data and cryptocurrency.
Lab content is a bit more practical I guess. It does teach some basic VBA, Microsoft access and machine learning ect. But the TA really does explain much on the reasoning behind each step.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Class is boring, he just reads ppt and it's so easy to lose focus. There's definitely a strong Korean accent, but it's easy to understand cus everything's on the slides.
I think some terms and theories are poorly explained, and its quite hard to understand just by reading the ppt.
But the professor is nice, and answer all the emails really fast.
reviews.comment_grading:
class participation 15%
lab 15% (10% final + 5% quiz)
group project 20%
midterm 20%
final 30%

try answering as many questions as you can in class, because the professor doesn't tell which question is credit worthy until you've answered. And sometimes comments he considers valuable can earn you extra credit.

Remember to attend industry week and don't skip other groups' presentation cuz it counts towards participation.

For the group project, he asked us to design an app, and write a business proposal first, then a presentation and a business plan. I recommend arranging a meeting with the professor before you submit the proposal to discuss you idea, he does give some useful advice and guidance so make sure you follow them. I would recommend sending your ppt to him before the presentation, he would give you helpful feedback and you can make some final adjustments.

exams are noncumulative. He tends to ask super tiny details about the slides, so you need to remember everything, especially the statistics, if you are aiming for a decent score. Mean is pretty high for the midterm, so its definitely competitive.

I scored around mean for midterm and got full mark on lab final and project proposals. Other scores are unreleased, but I got an A in the end. So I guess you just need to take the group project seriously and study hard for the final, try to participate more during class and also do the bonus assignment. The grading is quite generous.
reviews.comment_workload: Workload is ok. Group project takes some time, but other than that you just have to read through slides and try to remember them all.

reviews.author: solarski22
reviews.title: Swap for grades if you do not have a major yet
reviews.comment_content:
Lectures:
Digital Economy
E-Commerce
Platform Economy
Business Analytics and Big Data
Crowdsourcing

The names above maybe be interesting and useful, but the teaching content of them are pretty useless and boring, especially if you are not interested in IS/business. The whole course is just like telling you that IS helps a lot, and then it is done, nothing concrete learnt. Also, the content are unorganized. Shouldn't expect too much from it.

Labs: (separate from the lecture part)
Web Analytics
Business Analytics using Microsoft Excel
Advanced Business Analytics
Database using Microsoft Access
Big Data Analytics

It is more useful than the lectures. Some are interesting.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The professor is sometimes funny. His teaching is not too bad. He is sometimes nice and enthusiastic in teaching. However, his slides are too simplified, and the teaching flow is quite unorganized.  There are also a lot of limitations for the project and the process of asking him questions. His lectures are sometimes boring, that's also related to the content. His major problem is his assessment method and grade distributions.

I think it is okay to be in his class if you have already chosen your major. But if you have not, and you really need good CGA, then he will break your plan.

The lab and lecture TA Olivia is nice and cute, she is helpful and responsible.
reviews.comment_grading:
Course Participation 15%
Labs 15%
Group Project 20%
Midterm Exam 20%
Final Exam 30%

The grading is bad. His exam questions are useless and controversial. The MC questions are either too easy or ambiguous, and the questions fail to identify who knows the content well and who doesn't. He will tell you some beautiful words saying that his exams are fair, well-prepared, and the grading is fair, hard work good grades, someone did bad in mt and got A at last, etc... Don't trust him, his grades are very bad.
reviews.comment_workload:
Not light. The major workload comes from:
1. The project presentation
2. The project report
3. The project brainstorming and discussions
4. Giving (good) comments for other groups who have presented (it counts towards your participation mark)
5. Rating about 70 comments from other students

reviews.author: kaz
reviews.comment_content: Introduction on Information Systems, including Ecommerce, digital economy and AI. Won't go into deep, you just need to know the terms and the concepts.
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor has obvious accent but it is bearable and he explained the concepts pretty well, at least you could understand the logic behind.
reviews.comment_grading:
The final exam is divided into 2 parts, labs and lectures.
For lab part, it is simply and you could actually gain over 95% if you have attended the lessons. The lecture part contains a lot of essay questions and I do not have enough time to finish all. But it turned out is above mean. The presentation is easy and majority of students get high marks. Overall, it is easy to get good grade.
reviews.comment_workload: No heavy workload. Only need to finish midterm, final exam and presentation. But it counts participation in class, so better attend all of them.

reviews.author: revennanddi
reviews.comment_content: Basic ISOM concept learning extremely fundamentally and abstractly
reviews.comment_teaching:
He talks about how to apply the concept quite well. However, any discussion you found in the lecture will not be tested in exam. So generally the lecture is a good way for you to polish shoes(擦鞋). Your aim is making Tat Koon remembers your name, so that you will get a good score in the project presentation.
One good thing is that there is lecture recording.

But overall, I slept every meaningless lesson, which is not helpful for final exam
reviews.comment_grading:
Industry week and reading assignments (5%)(everyone get full mark)
Group project evaluation (10%) not released
Group project presentation (10%)  12/15 Mean 12.4 Min 10.5 Max 13.3
Group project report(10%) 13/15 Mean 12.9 Min 11 Max 13.5
Midterm (20%) 20/23 Mean 16.3 Max 23
Final (30%) 55/56 Mean 45.2 Max 56 Min 7 SD 9.6
Lab Quiz(5%) Everyone got full
Lab Exam (10%) 49/50 Mean 40 Max 50 (thanks chan hiu ting)

This course still have business school characteristics: it tests how careful you are

Hint 1: Lab Exam is very similar to the Lab Quiz, and make sure you know who is making the paper(this sem is Chan Hiu Ying, do not waste time to ask or learn from other irrelevant TA)
Hint 2: The final exam this sem consists of 13 marks MC, 14 marks of SQ(pricing of platform, what is primary key) and 29 marks of SQL
Hint 3: Tat koon True False question is rubbish. In midterm, the answer of all six question is false

Final Letter Grade: A
reviews.comment_workload: Work loadis quite okay

Especially for the project, her guiding questions were so vague that we do not know really know what she wants. But when we asked her for a sample, she said she did not have one. PPT slides are quite dull. Most importantly, it is almost impossible to reach her directly with her email for questions and project consulting. You must reach her through the TA. reviews.comment_grading:
Grading is decent. However, although I got much above the mean in the midterm and final, I only got a B because the group project was at mean, and my lab final exam (10%) was quite below mean.

So even if you understand the lecture content and do well for the exams, do not neglect the lab content like i did :P

Participation 15% (easy)
Lab 15% (5% online quizzes-unlimited tries, 10% lab final exam)
Group project 20% (instructions aren't that clear)
Midterm exam 25% (MCQ, few short answer)
Final exam 25% (short answer)
reviews.comment_workload: Workload was light. Just go over lecture slides- very easy to understand. It is helpful to note down some of his comments from class- that way you have more information about the topics to write about on the final which was a short-answer exam (simple questions).

reviews.comment_teaching:
The professor has a poor accent and as he only need us to be involved in the discussion by typing in the chatbox, people only copy what the other typed.
(Sometimes one typo will affect all the comment below as people don't care whether it is correctly spelled or not)
I cannot understand what he was saying so I just log in zoom and let it go. I don't take the lectures at all and I think it will be even better if you just copy the name of the concept and google it. He is just reading out the ppt slides and with nothing else to explain. So don't waste you time my friend.

For the project, that made me extermely angry.
Originally we have 22 minutes for presentaiton and this stupid instructor just changed into 16 one day before the deadline of submitting the ppt. Is he stupid??? He said it was because we may not have enough time to finish the presentation while ensure that the lecture will ends on time. Did you do the calculation before you told us that we have 22 minutes to present? Why do you need to say that one day before the deadline? We had to delete a lot of the contents and make everything become shorter in the end and that made me think our own project is dead.

reviews.author: thomaschh
reviews.comment_content: Interesting stuff but very general; you get to know some of the bigger ideas in the field but you don't get an in-depth view. On the plus side, this means that the content covered will not be overly complicated and it is not too difficult to get good grades as long as you pay attention in class.
reviews.comment_teaching: Good teaching in general. Some comment that the instructor just read from slides, but in reality this is often not the case, though additional material mostly comes from questions from students. These additional material, of course, are not covered in exams; but necessary if you really want to use what you learnt in intern contexts.
reviews.comment_grading: Because the content is relatively easy compared to other courses; expect that your peers will perform better compared to other courses. It is easy to get a good mark, but not so a good grade. The group project is not too difficult either and you could get a good grade on that so long as there are not free riders.
reviews.comment_workload: Light workload. Expect to spend less time in this course than others. The exam; tests and projects cover mostly basic-level stuff and common sense could get you a long way.

reviews.author: Heliumet
reviews.title: Labs are more useful than lectures
reviews.comment_content:
The course includes theorems about how business uses information, and examples such as crowd-funding, cryptocurrencies, google searching, etc. Quite a lot of small discussions in class (not counted to grades).

For lab session, Microsoft Excel, VBA, Access and basics of google machine learning (multi linear regression) are included.
reviews.comment_teaching:
1.5 hours lecture, 2 per week. Mostly reading powerpoint and watching related videos. Some class discussions on the topic. Before exam there will be a "revision guide", good enough if you follow the guide to prepare for the exam.

1 hour lab session per week (likely to overrun). Useful as introducing codes for VBA and Access.

Generally lecturers and TAs are nice and are willing (and capable) to answer students' questions.
reviews.comment_grading:
Attendence: Industry Talk (5%)
Lab quizzes (5%)
Midterm (20%)
Project (20% + 10% peer evaluation)
Final exam (30% lecture + 10% lab)

In the syllabus it is stated that 15% of grades are in class attendence, but actually 5% corresponds to industry talk (attend 2 talks that lasts about 2 hours each) and 10% in peer evaluation in group project, which means basically you can skip all classes if you like.

There are 10 lab quizzes in total, normally each having 5 MCs. Unlimited attempts are allowed so you can basically make it all correct.

Midterm and Final have very high mean as the questions are easy (around 80% - 85%)

Group project part is one big project to develop a product that uses information technology as the main part. A complete proposal report as well as financial budget and pitching powerpoint are needed. 5 people in a group and self-groupings are allowed.

As people having similar scores in midterm and final, if you make some careless mistakes in exams or fried up the group project, you will get a bad grade; but if you stand out a bit from others, you are close to A range.
reviews.comment_workload:
The heaviest part of workload is on the group project. It takes up 1 to 2 months for the whole process of idea generation, decide on product details, doing research and finally finalise a report. As self-grouping is allowed, better to get to know some friends before you join this class (it will be good if you are in a major and have some friends in the same major you know as they are likely to be preregistered in the same session).

Besides the main project, each week there is a lab quiz to be completed, which takes only about 5 to 30 minutes based on whether you really understand the content in lab session.

reviews.author: Karlbear
reviews.title: GREAT Professor and TA
reviews.comment_content:
Although it is an introductory course to Information System, the lecture focuses little on coding, only basic knowledge of SQL. It mainly introduces technology concepts and trends, including Digital Economy, E-commerce, Online Platforms, Business Analytics, Big Data Analytics and Financial Technology. The content is not difficult, not practical and sometimes a bit boring.

The lab part would teach you some basic knowledge of Google Website, Excel, VBA, SQL and Big Data.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Because of the content, I always lose my concentration and play my mobile phone. But I would say Muller tries his best to explain concepts very detailedly and patiently with some examples. He is also willing to answer students' questions during and after class. So reg his lecture and you would never regret!

TA Samuel is also nice and patient. I think he is cute as he would use some interesting emojis when replying your emails.
reviews.comment_grading:
I don't know other professors, but Muller actually gives a good grade. Although I mess up my final, I still got an A.
Grading as follows:
Class Participation:
Industry week(5%): attend two talks and you can get full marks
Online Discussion(10%): 4 topics throughout the semester
Labs:
Lab Quiz(5%): 10 quizzes after attending labs, unlimited attempts, easy to get full marks
Lab Final10%): 20 minutes to finish 14 questions (MCQ and Fill-in-blank), due to the time limit, not easy
Group Project(20%): 12-minute-Presentation and 8-page-report. Think of a creative idea of an online platform/app, use concepts taught in class and you can get a satisfactory grade.
Midterm(20%): 50 minutes to finish 6 short essay questions
Final(30%): 30 minutes to finish 4 short essay questions, including SQL.
The exam is not cumulative.

I got full in participation, high in Midterm, above 0.5 sd in Lecture Final, 0.8sd in Lab Final, 18.4/20 in Group Project, turn out an A.
So the grade is SUPER GOOD.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is moderate. Given the exam was both open-book, I didn't need to memorize concepts and saved lots of time. For group projects, my groupmates were SUPER good, so I did not spend too much time on the presentation and report. I would say the workload is OK.

reviews.author: CocoY
reviews.title: Pretty Professor with good grading
reviews.comment_content:
Two parts in this course:
Lecture:
The content is not difficult. Some of them are just common sense and some are theories. You need to understand the concept and also recite some main points (e.g. VRIO model, characteristics of two-sided market)
1. Overview
2. Digital Economy 1
3. Digital Economy 2

reviews.comment_teaching:
The professor is quite nice. She would answer the students' questions patiently. In the lesson, usually she just read the PowerPoint slides and that's a little bit boring. But her PowerPoint slides are quite clear. If you miss a lesson, it's pk to just go through the slides yourself.

For the lab, due to online learning, the TAs would provide a video recording every week so that you can watch it yourself according to your own pace. But some TAs have a heavy Hong Kong accent, making his English so weird.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading in this semester is really good although some said Prof. Baek's grading was bad in the previous semesters.
The midterm was pretty easy while the final was hard. For the lab, I think it is quite easy for those who learnt coding.

I got B+ finally. Overall, I just got the marks at mean (while I don't know the participation marks) The grading is pretty good.

Statistics:
Midterm (20%):
Mean: 86.99/100 (SD: 9.61)
Me: 97/100

Final (30%):
Mean: 35.92/60 (SD: 7.99)
Me: 30/60

Project (20%):
Depends on your presentation, a business report and peer evaluation
Mean: Not Provided
Me: 16/20

Lab Quiz (5%):
Should get full mark (MCQ with unlimited attempt)

Lab Exam (10%):
Mean: 22.05/30 (SD: 5.34)
Me: 28/30

Class Participation (15%):
Not disclosed
Need to attend 2 industry talks (or you need to write reviews)
Need to attend the class with project presentation and give some useful comments to your classmates
reviews.comment_workload:
- midterm (lecture only)
- final exam (for both lecture part and lab part)
- 1 project (presentation and a business report)
- lab quiz every week (very easy --- MCQ with unlimited attempt)

The workload is not heavy. As the lecture content is quite easy and not as much as other courses, the workload is okay to have one more project.

For the presentation, not only a beautiful PowerPoint, you also need to design a prototype to show the interface of your business idea. So it is quite important to find teammates with good art sense. For the business report, just write something related to IS concept/theory. You would find 8 pages (max. limit) are not enough to elaborate all your idea.

reviews.author: Wolfheart
reviews.title: The Definition of "Information Overload"
reviews.comment_content:
Lecture:
[Midterm] Digital Economy, E-Commerce
[Lecture Final] Google and Online Platform, Social Media Management, Databases and Business Analytics, FinTech

Lab:
1 - Web Analytics (Google Sites & Google Analytics)
2 - Excel (Functions: AND, OR, IF, COUNTIF, SUMIF, VLOOKUP)
3-5 - Basic VBA (mostly learning structure of syntax)  
6-8 - Database using Microsoft Access
9-10: Big Data Analytics using Azure

Lecture exams are non-cumulative. Lab finals will test only knowledge from Labs 2-8. There will be an "Industry Week" in the middle of the semester to talk about IS stuff for 1h 30mins per talk.

Overall, lecture content is okay and lab content is pretty interesting.

For the lecture portion, this is purely a memorisation course. This semester was open-book because of online class. I asked the T.A. about why I did poorly in the midterm. Apparently, they grade based on markscheme so don't even bother with alternative explanations (e.g. from personal knowledge).

It's ironic how this course taught about "information overload" as one of the jargons, because it would be a representation of it.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Like with past reviews of this course and this professor, good luck trying to stay awake during lectures. I attended 100% of lectures so I can say that you'll be fine skipping like 80% of them. Accent is bearable, but professor reading from the slides is extremely boring. Kudos to the palpable effort though. Before the midterm and lecture final, there is a Q&A session so maybe attend that. For the midterm, sample MCQs were discussed in class so go to the last two sessions. For the lecture final, there were no practices, just the Q&A.

Professor's good when it comes to the ADP. Consult your ideas with her and try to make an impression, since scores for this component are undisclosed.

Contact T.A. Samuel if you want to ask about grades and some lab stuff. In-person checking is allowed but for online, he gives a breakdown of MCQ score and tips on the essay portion (based on experience asking for midterm).

Really enjoyed T.A. Olivia Chan who was assigned to my Lab. She is kind and energetic during labs, while being responsive to e-mails in terms of both time and comprehensiveness (which really helps for the lab finals).
reviews.comment_grading:
Breakdown:
[15%] Class Participation - 5% Industry Week attendance, 10% ADP participation based on peer review
[15%] Labs - 5% Weekly Quiz, 10% Lab Finals
[20%] Application Development Project (ADP)
[20%] Midterm (8 MCQs, 2 essays with subparts, 50mins)
[30%] Lecture Finals (8 MCQs, 2 essay questions, 50mins shared with Lab Finals)

Statistics (in percentage of course grade):
Midterm (mean: 16.16/20, SD: 2.02, max: 20)
Lecture Final (mean: 25.44/30, SD: 3.18, max: 30)
Lab Final (mean: 6.86/10, SD: 2.46, max: 10)

My Scores:
Midterm (14.55/20; 0.7sd below)
Lecture Final (29.1/30; 1.15sd above)
Lab Final (8.67/10; 0.7sd above)
Full marks: Industry Week, Lab Quiz
Unknown: ADP, Class Participation

Final score: A-

Course has high means. Like in previous years, scores on the ADP are undisclosed. It's probably just based on the effort you put because the grading criteria is truly questionable (imagine a 3-page report with TNR 12 and double-spacing; idk how anyone can be comprehensive enough). I believe that final grade is consistent to previous years' grading, so fair enough.
reviews.comment_workload:
Light workload overall. Weekly labs aren't too difficult. Industry Week just requires either attendance or a 250-word reflection paper for full marks.

ADP consists of 5-6 people, with the liberty to choose groupmates. It's fine as long as you're not with free-riders.

The workload is just reserved to familiarising yourself with the lab final content. In a physical semester, this would be memorising every concept for both midterm and lecture final. However, in an online semester, just remember where each concept is in your notes and then copy explanations word-for-word.

Also don't take coding SQL for-granted. I have reason to believe that exams from previous years are just repeated, so listen to previous years' reviews. Learning this hits two birds with one stone for the Database topic in both lecture and lab finals.

reviews.author: ustkatielaw
reviews.comment_content:
Before Midterm:
Digital Economy
E-Commerce

After Midterm (non-cumulative):
Online Platforms
Business Analytics
Big Data Analytics
Industry Week (just go to talks)
Emerging Technology: FinTech

Most of them are pretty basic IS concepts. Yanzhen has this study guide for exams. Know the keywords (what they mean and how to use them) and read through the powerpoints should suffice.

Note that the topics for this course is the same for all professors, but the content will be slightly different. Yanzhen is more about the big picture rather than going on some detailed Fintech or IS ideas.

She asked us to know how to write SQL though (basic level) so it was the same thing as the lab sessions.
reviews.comment_teaching:
I gave Yanzhen a B simply because of her effort. She is not the best professor (bad accent, read through the powerpoint every lecture), but you can tell she tried her best. She is also very responsive to our questions. I skipped 80% of the lecture though since there's no attendance.

the TAs are pretty nice and friendly in the lab sessions as well.
reviews.comment_grading:
Class Participation: 15%
I think everyone gets full marks for this part. basically go to the industry week talks (be present or submit an evaluation afterwards) and you will get 5%. For this semester, the professor just gave the remaining 10% to everyone (I think) if there are no problems with your group project or peer-evaluation

Mid-term: 20%
I got slightly above mean for the mid-term (like 0.4 points above or some sort). Make sure you get full marks on the Multiple choice questions as they weigh 4 marks each (same as a short-answer question). One mistake I made is I wrote too much on the short answers but couldn't get the keywords/concepts right.

Final Exam: 30%
Same format as the midterm exam. I got 0.5sd above the mean this time. Again, losing points in MCQs are deadly, so just be careful

Group Project: 20% (grades not released)

form a group of 4-5 people and work on an IS-related innovation. The report is 3-page in terms of length but there's no need for presentation this semester due to everything being online. Not very tough but make sure you get good groupmates.

Labs: 15%
There are two parts: the actual lab sessions (5%) and the lab final exam (10%).
for the lab sessions, everyone should get full marks (unless you forgot to do the quiz). Quizzes are just 4/5 MCQs, you don't have to listen to the lab and you can still get full marks from it LOL
The lab final exam is quite demanding as you only have 20 minutes to do it. The questions are quite close to the lab quizzes but more challenging. I got full marks here.
reviews.comment_workload: Pretty Light For a 3-credits course. Most workload comes from the Group Project. The rest is pretty simple.

reviews.author: grindingalways
reviews.title: Great Professor
reviews.comment_content:
Content is actually quite interesting and is not really that difficult to comprehend (at least for muller's section). Content is basically the same across different instructors with little variations depending on the particular interests of the professor:
1. Digital Economy
2. E-Commerce
3. Online Platform
4. Business Analytics
5. Big Data Analytics
6. Fintech
And these subjects are hot terms in modern society so no harm learning more about them!
reviews.comment_teaching:
So I actually was not pre-reg to muller cheung's course at the beginning. I have attended Chen yanzhen's class for several times and got (unexpectedly) swapped to muller's class on the last day or so in the add-drop period. I was depressed at first because I just got adapted to the teaching style of Chen, and also I deadly thought I wouldn't succeed in swapping so I just kept my waiting list there without withdrawing it. Anyway, this turns out to be a great decision!

As a person who has come across 2 professors' teaching, here is an honest comparison: Muller>>>Chen.

Even though it is the first year (I believe) that Muller taught ISOM2010, his teaching is really great and accent is much more understandable than Chen (makes a huge diff here cos you can barely learn anything from chen's class with her accent). And the notes are more well designed as well in comparison. If Muller will continue to teach this course in the future, I strongly recommend picking him!
reviews.comment_grading:
1. Class Participation 15%
2. Labs 15%
3. Group Project 20%
4. Midterm Exam 20%
5. Final Exam 30%

1. Class participation consists of industry week participation and discussion (4 boards in total) participation.
2. Lab consists of 5% for lab quizzes on Canvas (with unlimited attempts) and 10% for lab exam (quite tricky). Lab teaches you some Excel skills, VBA and Microsoft Access. Spent quite a lot of time on them because I am not really a tech savvy.
3. Group project consists of presentation (around 12 mins) and business plan (like an executive summary). It is about having an innovative idea (like an app, a technology etc) that incorporates the concept words you have learned in the course.
4/5. Midterm exam and final have super limited time. In this special semester they change to short questions from MCQ according to professor, so the time is really in a rush. But i guess this problem won't exist anymore in the upcoming semesters where MCQ can very likely take place again idk.

1. 15/15
2. 5/5+9/10 (lab exam mean 6.35/10, sd 2.39)
3. 19.2/20
4. 17/20 (mean 13.92/20, sd 2.67)
5. 30/30 (didn't expect this at all!) (mean 21.28/30, sd 4.99)

Grade: Not yet released, will update later
(Update: A+)
reviews.comment_workload: Harsh. The course (lecture part) is designed to be a little bit easier because other parts like group project and lab take up the other workload. Still, hard work pays off!

reviews.author: Boeing787
reviews.comment_content:
Course Overview:
Digital Economy (I)
Digital Economy (II)
Digital Economy (III)
E-Commerce (I)
E-Commerce (II)
E-Commerce (III)
E-Commerce (IV)
Online Platforms (I)
Online Platforms (II)
Business Analytics
Big Data Analytics
Industry Week (I)
Industry Week (II)
Big Data Analytics (II)
Emerging Technology: FinTech

This course provides a broad coverage of technology concepts and trends underlying current and future developments in information technology (IT), and fundamental principles for the effective use of computer-based information systems.  There will be a special emphasis on e-commerce, business integration and IT management.  Other topics include: hardware/software, networking, the Internet and World Wide Web (WWW), databases, security, and enterprise applications.  In additional to the fundamental conceptual and propositions in the IS area, a number of business applications and cases will be discussed; the newest trend in today’s technology domain will also be discussed.
reviews.comment_teaching: It is evident that Professor Chen attempts to make an effort in delivering quality teaching. However, her performance is sub-standard. Her lectures are boring and most content can be reviewed by looking at lecture slides. However, she is patient at answering questions and dealing with enquiries. Not a great professor but at least she tries. Some professors don't even seem like they care, which is 10 times worse.
reviews.comment_grading:
Class Participation 15%
There are two aspects of  class participation: in class activities (e.g., surveys, self-tests, reading assignments) and Industry Week talks (5%). 10% goes to group project work evaluation.

Labs 15%
5% from in-class quizzes and 10% from final exam. The final exam was so difficult for the lab section!

Group Project 20%
Pick good group members. However, the workload isn't too high since there's no need for a presentation.

Midterm Exam 20%

Final Exam 30%

The midterm was fairly straightforward, while finals were quite difficult. There were too many questions in a 50 minute exam setting.
reviews.comment_workload:
Average workload. You have a midterm, final and a project. The midterms and final were very short, both at 50 minutes. This is a blessing, as we have 3 hour long exams in FINA 2303. The project isn't too much of a hassle, especially if you have good group members. I am lucky to be with a good team and I'm glad Professor Chan allows us to choose our group members.

Professor Chan does not require a presentation for the project, which eases the workload of it. We need to turn in a 3 page report and 6-slide long roadshow slide, which is fairly easy to handle.

For industry week, we were required to attend two zoom talks. These were counted in our participation mark.

reviews.author: wingsn
reviews.comment_content:
Digital Economy
1. Explain data, information, and information systems.
2. Know the meaning of Moore’s law, Metcalf’s law and their implications.
3. Understand the implications of globalization.
4. Discuss the use of information systems in organizations.
5. Describe the newer aspects of working in the digital world.
6. Define ethics and describe the major ethical problems posed by the digital world.
Ecommerce
1. Describe the nature of e-business.
2. Define the e-business value chain and disintermediation.
3. Describe the basic e-business models.
4. Examine the major online marketing methods.
5. Discuss the major issues that are created by and affect e-business.
Social Media
1. Describe the key component of social media.
2. Explain the 3 features of social media authoring.
3. Understand the meaning of Tagging.
4. Explain the differences between traditional and social media.
Technical Foundations
1. Identify the major components of hardware and networking technology.
2. Identify the different types of software.
3. Describe the process in software development.
4. Discuss the trends in hardware and software, and the implications to businesses.
ISOM 2010, Hong Xu
3
Big Data
1. Explain how organizations use data and information.
2. Explain the basic concepts of data management (data creation, sharing, mining, reporting).
3. Define database management systems (DBMS) and describe their various functions.
4. Data storage within and across organizations.
5. Explain how the relational database model works.
6. Describe how databases are developed.
7. Explain how organizations can use data warehousing and data mining for decision making.
8. Describe advanced database models and when their use is appropriate.
Business Analytics and Decision Makings
1. Discuss the problems associated with management decision-making.
2. Explain the specific information needs of managers in different functional areas of an organization, including production, operations, marketing and sales, accounting, human resources and IT.
3. Explain the decision-making process.
4. Explain the increasing roles and responsibilities of accountants as user and owner of data and the corporate information system.
5. Describe decision support systems.
6. Describe the opportunities and threats to corporate information system including capabilities in data treatment and analysis, data integrity, system security and issues in access restriction, and business contingency/continuity.
7. Discuss the roles and trend of IT in business analytics and decision making
Business, Accounting and Finance
1. Formulate appropriate information systems strategies to support implementation of business and functional strategies.
2. Use the system development life cycle to plan, design, implement, and evaluate an IT system.
3. Describe the application of information technology to accounting systems and the generation, reporting, internal control and attestation of accounting information.
4. Recognize and understand the roles of accountants in all stages of the system development life cycle: systems analysis; systems design; systems implementation; and systems operation and maintenance.
5. Demonstrate an understanding of the behavioral issues of implementing information systems in organizations.
6. Describe how change management can contribute to successful implementation of information systems.
Technology-Enabled Business Trends
1. Identify major tech-enabled trends in near future
2. Examine impact of tech-enabled trends on individuals, firms, and society
3. Discuss business opportunities of new technologies

reviews.comment_teaching:
She's a good teacher and has great insights. She's likes when people participate in class. She uses a lot of videos also.

Though she answers questions in class, and even if you're just asking a simple clarification, she'll think you're challenging her and she becomes very defensive of her point. Her tone is a bit monotonous, making the class slightly boring. She also sits in her chair all class long and rarely moves around.

My group project had 3 free-riders and we reported them. She realised that my friend and Ihad done all the work and she said she'll change the individual scores accordingly. I feel that was the main reason behind my A.
reviews.comment_workload:
The lab quizzes are very easy to score in; it's just 5 questions in each quiz with unlimited attempts. The lab final was quite challenging.

Participation is quite easy: just contribute in class, attend lectures (she takes iPRS randomly), and attend the industry talks.

Her instructions for the group project are quite vague. Make sure your group meets her in person to get the idea approved. She has a very specific idea in her mind of what she's looking. We kept giving her our proposals at the end of every class and she kept telling "that's not what I'm looking for", etc. She approved our 7th proposal.

Midterm and final have a mix of MCQs and short-answer questions. The midterm had a lot of memorisation but the final was more application-based.

reviews.author: Edrick
reviews.title: Low workload, Easy course
reviews.comment_content:
The previous part of the course is about the use of information system in different businesses, she provided a lot of examples of company using information system to create change in the market.
Second part is about the SQL language, which is easy and shallow. There is lab session which will help you better understand the concepts and encounter difficulties. The tutors are all very nice and helpful.
The last part is the cryptocurrency, she only explained the background and some mechanism behind. I will say you can go through all the materials on Youtube in 1 or 2 hours.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof is basically reading the lecture notes, but there is some fun videos in between, so I would say it is quite fun.

She is very eager to answer questions, but only through direct conversation, seldom reply emails. She also provides study guides before midterm and final, as well as discussion sessions during the ADP projects.
reviews.comment_grading:
There is 1 midterm and group project, as well as final exam.

Both the midterm and final exam are divided into 2 parts: MC and Short Questions. Short questions are easy, just a dictation of lecture notes. However, the MCs are critical to your grade because they takes 6 marks per question in midterm and 3 marks per question in final exam.

In the final exam, there is also a lab section that examine all the knowledge taught in the lab session.

The Application Development Project is to propose a business idea which leverage the advantage of mobile application. You have to apply some knowledge and analyzing tools in lectures. Generally, you get high marks if you spend enough time on it, grades are not deviated in this part.

Therefore, you can score high marks if you spent enough time to understand and remember the terms and jargon in the lecture notes.

Midterm: 98/100
ADP: don't know
Final: 94.75/104
Grade: A+
reviews.comment_workload:
There are quite a lot of materials that you have to memorize, but there is a industrial weeks which you only have to attend to talks to get participation marks.

The ADP project is not difficult since you are in a team of 5 to 6 members.

reviews.author: letter
reviews.title: Don't know why so many people think he is bad
reviews.comment_content:
course content includes database & analytics, online platform, big data, crowdsourcing, digital economy, and e-commerce.
lab session includes Business Analytics using Microsoft Excel, Advanced Business Analytics and Database using Microsoft Access.
the group project is about developing an app and apply the things learned in class.
reviews.comment_teaching:
tat koon gives many real-life examples so the content is very easy to understand. His lesson is very interesting.
There is lecture video online so you actually no need to attend the lecture. Only the lab session is required to take attendance.
reviews.comment_grading:
For reference, the score distribution and my score for a A+,
Class Participation15% (5% for attending the industry week and reading-assignment) (10% for commenting other's presentation)
don't know my score on this part but I did my job on that 5% part so this part is full I guess
Labs 15%
- 5% canvas quiz (unlimited attempt) 5/5
- 10% exam (most of them are mc, some are fill-in the banks) 45/50
group project 20% (every group is more or less the same score so it doesn't differentiate you)
  presentation 12/15
  report 13/15
Midterm Exam 20% (all mc question) 22/23
Final Exam 30% 54/56
I think the competition is very tight. You have to do everything well throughout the whole semester to get a high grade.
Work hard and bless you:)))))
reviews.comment_workload:
the workload is acceptable.
won't take attendance on the lecture.
but the final score is separate into many small parts so you have to constantly give effort on this course.
I think the large part of the workload goes to the group project but the score is more or less the same between different groups, max 1-2 marks. Everything needs to be done in a short time.

reviews.author: UST Duke Lam
reviews.title: Not so good grade, new professor
reviews.comment_content:
There are 6 main parts in this course:
Before midterm:
1. Digital Economy
2. E-commerce

After midterm:
1. Online Platforms
2. Business Analytics
3. Big Data Analytics
4. Emerging Technologies (Bitcoin)

In my opinion, the course content is a bit scattered. The course content consists of many basic contents without digging deep into anything. It is literally an "introductory course". I would give the content grade a "C" if I wasn't that interested in IS.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor Baek Jiye is a new professor in HKUST. I don't think she had much teaching experience, so her first few lessons were either too long or too short due to bad planning and time management. However, her teaching got much better towards the end of the semester. She delivers any main point in a good manner, and her powerpoint slides were organized and easy to follow.

Her voice is quite soft. I took her 9am lecture, and believe me, as a student without a hall, you will definitely fall asleep in her lesson. On the other hand, she listens to students' opinions and tries to improve her teaching in the process. When some students pointed out that her voice was too soft, she brought a louder mic in the following lesson in the hopes that we will be satisfied. Although I would not say she is the best professor as she still has a lot of room for improvement, I appreciate her attitude towards students and teaching.
reviews.comment_grading:
She's a new professor, as I mentioned, so her grading was the most unpredictable out of the 3 professors who taught in 2018/19 spring (Koh Tat Koon and Chen Yanzhen). In the beginning, I would expect that her grading will follow the 20%-40%-40% guideline strictly.

After I received my grade, I would only say the grading is fair. Her grading is not exceptionally bad, at least from my perspective. Here are my stats in examinations:
Midterm: above mean ~0.5sd
Final: below mean ~0.5sd
Lab: maximum (above mean ~1sd)
Attendance: all full except I missed one reflection on industry week
Project: around mean (slightly below)
Participation: should be full, stat not provided

Final Grade: B

I think it is quite fair. However, I heard from someone from the 10:30 session, where he/she got a mean score on essentially everything and got a C-. I also heard others saying that the mean is on C range. Unpredictable. I guess I was lucky?
reviews.comment_workload:
I would say a normal workload for a 3 credit course. There are no assignments and quizzes. There's only 1 midterm and then a final for examinations. And then there's a project, which consists of a proposal (2%), presentation (10%) and a business plan (8%). Towards the end of the semester, the workload noticibaly increased as you would need to complete the presentation and business plan within like 2 weeks.

Also, you would need to attend a 1-hour long lab session every week on top of your normal lecture. The lab session, unlike the lecture, is compulsory and attendance is required. You would need to spend more lesson time compared with a normal business core course, which does not have any labs/tutorials.

reviews.author: zkel
reviews.comment_content:
Lecture
1. Digital Economy
2. E-commerce
3. Social Media Management
4. Online Platform
5. Database and Business Analytics
6. FinTech, including bitcoin and blockchain

Lab
1. Excel Built-in Function
2. Excel VBA
3. Microsoft Access, including SQL Language
4. BIgData Analytics

The content of the course is quite useful I think, though it is not really related to IS. For Lecture, it gives you a broad view on the business world nowadays and the lab session teaches you technical skills which is very useful in work.
It is worth studying I think.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Her teaching is not god I think.
Although I can see her effort in preparing notes and teaching us everything useful, she has a bad speaking skill and she cannot properly present what she want to say to us
However her notes are OK and it is enough for you to prepare for midterm and final.
Therefore, you can simply just read the notes and skip all the lecture and you will still be able to get a decent grade. (In fact many people disappeared after midterm exam)

reviews.comment_content: Introduction to basic Information System concepts. Such as network platforms, eCommerce, Database, Big Data, Analytics, etc. One can't really say these are not useful, yet they are all covered at a more macro level and nothing in-depth. This would be understandable in an introductory course.
reviews.comment_teaching: TK is an enthusiastic teacher who is willing to engage with his students. He is highly responsive, can be easily reached by email. Class environment is good, yet when he tries to stimulate interaction, it usually fails. Perhaps students are not so confident to participate in my session.
reviews.comment_grading:
SD is too small.

Assessment methodology is not set properly to differentiate students.  Therefore, a small lapse in any component (e.g. attendance) may have dramatic impact on your grade. Make sure you get all the marks that you could.
reviews.comment_workload:
Light.

Group project is not very demanding, yet still dependent on the quality of group mates. No homework/assignment what so ever.

But the lecture itself is very sleepy, and sometimes I wonder the reason why there're so many pauses during her speech, is that she is translating her words from Korean to English.
She's a nice professor though, quite patient to listen to your thoughts or listening to your comments on the exam. Since she's 1st year to UST, we can figure out that she's been trying hard to adjust both the style of the class and the exams. But either midterm or final is a disaster to her students, just in different types.
reviews.comment_grading:
Bad grading with high means, ambiguous explanations and messy presentations.
The midterm is too easy, even for, say, more than 80% of the students. The mean of midterm is 87.4/100, with a high std of more than 5.
The final is too difficult and some answers even puzzled the TA. She failed to get the points of the prof.
Presentation offers similar scores among groups, but u can view all kinds of frustrating unrealistic ideas of mobile app during that day.

Final 30%

reviews.comment_teaching:

Lecture notes guided me throughout the entire course and I coped well with it.

A guiding list of questions and definitions would be provided before every exam which I found it to be very useful. Alot of things had to be googled but I found the process rewarding.
reviews.comment_grading:
Class Participation : 15%
Labs: 15%
Group Project: 20%
Midterm Exam: 20%
Finals: 30%

Class Participation is a scam, just attend the relevant talk, or if you can't, write the reflection letter. easy 15%.

You are allowed to choose your group members. Just make sure you choose the right people and don't let people free-ride. My group was fantastic and we completed the project in just 2 days. Consisting of 3 page proposals and 6 power point slides.

Finals consist of both lectures and lab content. Follow the guiding questions and you should fair fine.

Group: Unknown
