reviews.comment_teaching: Hilary is a funny guy, though not many people like him. He takes no BS. Makes you be active in class where you actually learn to code.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading tbh quite fair.

quizes: 12/15(full score 20, but only count up to 15 for errors, I missed like so many). For quiz, can use notebook to try out the combinations

1 assignment: quite challenging, but good preparation for final exam. score not released but I think I got full

Final: content not released, but 5 problem based questions, knew how to do 4, last one super hard, but attempted to do like the beginning part, left the rest of the question with #comments.

Even though I missed out on basically free marks for the quiz, and pretty much gave up on last question still got A. I think because most people find this course hard, so the mean is relatively lower.
reviews.comment_workload:
Too much for 1 credit. Expect 1+2 hours of lectures per week + Quiz for each lecture that expires the same day.

1 assingment + final

reviews.author: bigboi
reviews.title: Easy course with good grades
reviews.comment_content:
Most of the content is very easy to understand.
The one key takeaway from this course is the "strategic mindset", acquiring the knowledge is straightforward and everyone can do it, being strategic means you add unique value into what you are doing that stands out.

Strategic is key in applying technology in real life but even more important in designing our own lives. This course is amazing if you can far transfer the concept into your practical life.

This is my personal notes on what is taught:
(if the content is similar, you might as well use this as a reference for revision checklist)
Digital Economy
• Information
o Cost structure
o Consumption
 Experience good
• Trial
• Comment
 Information overload
• Personalized recommendations
• Search & filter
• Information – Tech
o Accessibility
o Enrichment
o Facilitate exchange
• Role of IS in business
o Operation
o Decision
o Competitive edge
 New market
 Loyalty
• Operational effectiveness
o Automation
o Process reengineering
o Agile system
o Necessary but non-differentiator
• Strategic IT
o Valuable
o Rare
o Inimitable
o Non-substitutable
• Big company facing new ideas (tech always become cheaper and better later on)
o Ignore
o Deny
o Hybrid
• Impact of IT
o Changing the target market
o Value proposition
o Price/quality trade-off
• IT in marketing
o Unofficial product info
o Point of sales and online distribution channel
o Dynamic pricing
o Personalized + interactive advertisement
o Viral marketing
• Digitalization of enterprise
o Leadership
o Execution efficiency
o Implementation scope
o Prioritization

E-commerce
• SCM (upstream)
• ERP (internal)
• CRM (downstream)
• Challenges of the adoption of software
o Resistant to change
o Learning curve
o Compatibility between departments
o Strategic use
• Software development process
o Requirements
o Design
o Development
o Verification
o Documentation
o Maintenance
• Strategic IT spending (which app function to develop first)
o Importance-Ease matrix
• Online advertising
o Type: Display/search
o Targeted
o Performance-based
o Flexibility
o Ad resistance
o Crowded space
o Fee: CPM, CPC, CPA
• Facebook advertising
o Active users
o Wide reach
o Identifiable users profile
o Purpose – ad match
o Adblock
• SEO
o Kw
o Metatags
o Popularity
• Long tail
o Make everything available
o Cut price
o Super start attracted,  guide customers to the long tail
• Network effect (how to beat open rice)
o Winner take all
o Adoption dynamics
 Move early
 Subsidize adoption
 Leverage viral promotion
 Increase in switching cost
 Make credible pre-announcement
Online Platforms
• Multi-sided networks
o Inter
o Intra
• Types of platforms
o Exchange
o Advertising-supported media
o Software platforms/consoles
o Transaction
• Pricing structure
o What: access or usage
o Who: charge people who value the inter-network effect more/inelastic
o How much: according to elasticity, time, people
Databases and Business Analytics
• Design of database
o What is database
o Establish relationships between tables
o 3 key relationships
• Coding specifics
o Join tables
o Aggregate information
• Data analytics
o Descriptive
o Predictive (us  company, provide predictive data) we are manipulative
o Prescriptive
Big data
• Characteristics
o Variety
o Volume
o Velocity
o Veracity
• Strategic use
o Decision  insight data
• Internet of Things
• Open data
Crowdsourcing
• Role of IS: aggregate solvers, disseminate problems
• Wise crowd
o Diversity of opinions
o Decentralization: everyone can say
o Independence
o Aggregation
• Strategic crowdsourcing
o Right crowd (fitting wise crowd)
o Motivate the crowd
o Complement external ideas with internal strength
reviews.comment_teaching:
TK is a good teacher, he interacts with students and he is good at using examples/real-life instances to explain.

If you only focus on acquiring what you need in the exam, you can just watch the lecture video in x2 speed. Sometimes I think he elaborated a little bit too much for simple content, so if you are good, just watch the video to save time.

What I learnt from him is not only IS basics but again the practice of strategic mindset, which I think is so valuable.
reviews.comment_grading:
I don't know why people say the grading is bad. It is important to know that everyone probably understands the content taught and did fair in the exam, so if you want good grades, you must be able to minimize careless mistakes in tests and give deeper insights in projects.

I worked hard, and I was lucky to have a few engaging teammates, I got very good grades.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is fair, and perhaps a little bit less compared to other 3 credit courses.

reviews.author: Tyy⭐️
reviews.comment_content: It looks simple. Some of them are common sense. I think the content is quite useful since it provides many basic knowledge of financial world, like blockchain technology.
reviews.comment_teaching: She is a new professor. I can feel her heart but her teaching is really not good... Just follow the PowerPoint and the PowerPoint is incomplete and she didnt make it clear when she spoke. Her ascent and pronounciation is a big problem. You will find no difference whether attend the lecture or not. But if you have any questions, you can email her or meet her directly, so that she will not be that nervous and provide a much more better explaination.
reviews.comment_grading: Very very good grading. New professor is usually lenient I think? I really couldnt understand the content due to the poor teaching and get a below mean in midterm（72,mean is 78）. My lecture final is above mean nearly 1sd and lab final is unknown(but i guess is at mean. With all other things being OK(did go to the industry week and did a OK project), I got a B+ which is better than my expectation.
reviews.comment_workload:
The only workload is ADP project. 6-7 people form a group and plan our own app to advert
ise it. It is not a very heavy job.

reviews.author: LLLEE
reviews.title: Not that Bad
reviews.comment_content:
- Lectures: SIX parts (week 1-9, 13)
Course Overview + Introduction of IS
Digital Economy
E-Commerce
Platform Economy
Business Analytics and Big Data
Emerging Technology

- Industry weeks: 2 talks attendance (week 10)

- Group Presentation: full attendance is required (week 11-12)

- Labs (10 compulsory LABs)

- Reading Assignments (3)
reviews.comment_teaching:
Not perfect, but not bad

Prof. Koh has good presentation skills and 80% of the time you won't fall asleep.
He gives vivid examples when explaining concepts.
Sometimes I got lost when I revised the lecture materials after class and realized that the materials covered during lectures are too simple/superficial, making things unclear to me.
reviews.comment_grading:
Disclaimer: I have got an A (overall: 91.37/100)

In %:
1. Participation (15%): 13.44/15
- Mean: 12.2 High: 14.7
2. Labs (15%): 12.33/15 (Mean: 11.76 High: 15)
- lab final: 25/30 (Mean: 22.01  High: 30  Low: 7)
- lab quiz: 4/5 (missed 2 quizzes)
3. Group Project (20%): 18.5/20
- presentation: 95/100 (Mean: 93.74 High: 97.5)
- report: 90/100 (Mean: 90.08 High: 92 Low: 89)
- seems like most of my friends from other groups also got 95/100 for the presentation
4. MT (20%):17.1/20
- midterm: 5.985/7
- MCQ, T/F (/6): Mean: 4.5 High: 6 Low: 2
- SQ (/1): Mean: 0.96 High: 1 Low: 0
5. Final (30%): 30/30
- lec final: 30/30 (Mean: 26.4 High: 30)


^For Course grade:
Your grade depends on your performances in all the grading components. Just doing well in one or two components (e.g., mid-term and final lecture exams) does not mean you will get the top grade. Broadly speaking:

A-range (A+, A, A-): very good scores (e.g., close to top scores) in almost all the components.
B+: good scores in almost all the components.
B: around average scores in the majority of the components; usually at least one component is quite high and the worst component is still close to average.
C+: Usually one component is quite low and the others are around average.

Do not ask me what "close", "very good", "good" means etc.; there is no specific cutoff or scores, but it depends on the relative performance of the whole class for the different components. At this point, there is nothing you and I can do to improve your final grade. Any emails concerning these will be politely ignored.
reviews.comment_workload:
Too complicated, too many "little" things to do, easy to miss out 1 or 2 things

*Lecture Midterm Exam (40 mins) - T/F, MCQ, Short-answer questions - [Qualtrics]

*Lab Final Exam (25 mins) - Mix of multiple choice and fill in the blank questions - [Canvas]

*Lecture Final Exam (50 mins) - True/False, MCQ, Short-answer questions, SQL statements - [Qualtrics]

*Industry Week -
You will get TWO participation counts (also regarded as full credit) if you:
- Get TWO successful registration offers, attend TWO talks in person via Zoom; OR
- Get ONE successful registration offer, attend ONE talk in person via Zoom.
PLUS watching ONE video of ANOTHER talk and submit ONE reflection; OR
- Watching the videos of TWO talks and submit TWO reflections.

*Project presentation (10%) and report (10%)  -
the scores shown are the pre-moderated score. All students in the same group will get the same score. However, the actual project score that goes into your final course grade could be affected by the peer evaluation.

*Project presentation feedback:
- a total of 9 feedbacks + live attendance x 3 (excluded attendance during your turns to present)

1. Attendance is compulsory
- You attend your registered section "Live" for all presentations (even if you and/or your group is not presenting on that day).

2. Feedback submission
- Only those who are NOT presenting need to submit feedback on that day.
- Deadline: 11.59 PM HKT on the day of the presentation (D day).
- Quality of your feedback matters (part of the course grade; refer to course outline).

3. Feedback rating
- You must rate all the feedback for your group by 11.59 PM HKT the day after your presentation (D+1 day).
- Once every member in your group has rated all the feedback, all of you will be able to see my feedback and comment about your presentation.
- If your group has a non-responsive member who does not complete the ratings by D + 1 (causing the group to not see my feedback), inform me of the situation via email on D + 2 (i.e., 2 days after your presentation).

*Lab Quizzes -
10 quizzes, each carries 0.5 marks, a total of 5 marks counted towards the course grade

*Reading Assignments -
- Read an article and answer 2-3 questions [Qualtrics]
For each assignment, you get:
- 5 points if you submitted before the deadline,
- 4 points if you submitted after the deadline,
- 0 point if you did not submit anything

reviews.author: chicken
reviews.title: The Professor from the Hell--Koh, Tat Koon. ISOM stands for Insane Singaporean Out of Medication
reviews.comment_content: The content is not interesting at all, I cannot learn anything from the lectures. For example, he talked about big data and how to use them, but he did not actually talk about how we can have access to such data or the methods or software that we can use to analyze the data. There are a lot of concepts which we can seldom apply to real life. His group projects are also extremely meaningless and I learnt nothing from it. He tried to have us to include some IS concepts in the development of the app, but those concepts will no longer be included in the final exam so it actually helps us nothing towards our learning.
reviews.comment_teaching: His powerpoint is so useless that we can hardly access the information we need for exam. Sometimes he will hide some key concepts or information and we must attend his lectures in order to get the missing part of the powerpoint. Yet, his lectures are actually extremely boring and not fun at all. He asks quite a number of questions but actually only international students will answer the questions. He does not even try to help local students to engage or to be involved more in the lectures deliberately. Moreover, his comment giving to group presentations, which is supposed to be the most useful for the groups for their final reports, are even shorter than those written by other students. I expected so much from his comments but turned out it did not help me even for any little bit.
reviews.comment_grading: I worked so hard for the mid-term exam but I still got below-mean, I seriously doubt that he only gives good grades to international students, and local students are the ones to suffer. His grading also depends a lot on the class participation. Although he says that class participation will not matter a lot on the grades, I am quite sure that he has weighting on the students' score (he claimed that he has upgraded all students' grades by multiplying each student's score by a certain constant) based on their participation. It is very unfair for people who are not that active but still worked hard on the exams.
reviews.comment_workload: There is not much to do so there is no place for us to exercise what we have learnt. We may apply the wrong concepts on the exams but we have no way to know as there is no homework to practise our learnings. He is too lazy to put up any homework but yet have the time and effort to make his own website, which does not work most of the time. Even when it works, it is loading at an extremely low speed. I expect him to put some homework on his website. Moreover, he put up some reading assignments but do not have any announcement to remind us to do the work. As a result, most people missed the first and some also missed the second one.

reviews.author: USTAsiaNo.0
reviews.title: 係你鬧個prof之前唔該睇清楚人地個grading requirement🤗
reviews.comment_content:
佢課堂上面教d乜我就唔再重覆啦，我諗其他review已經寫得好清楚。
有樣嘢幾interesting既係TK可以比我地揀d想學既野黎教，例如IoT, big data... 不過好老實講，我自己溫書果陣有時都會有d confused，究竟我溫既野關唔關ISOM事，有陣時佢ppt入面d point望落都幾common sense下，但不過你唔上佢堂又真係未必up得翻果d point出黎。
另，lab教既野幾有用，會教你點用vba同big data mining。
reviews.comment_teaching:
真心TK係一個好有heart既prof，成日會叫我地比d feedback佢，想improve teaching。（雖然佢d sfq我一次都無填過🤫）
唔係講technical野既話，TK其實都幾humorous（又或者係我笑點低:0) )
不過問心果句，佢d lect真係幾悶下，成個sem我attendance都唔知有無3成，就算有上堂你好快就會頂唔順，同你d frd傾計，事關上lect果陣你會覺得佢講野好悶，全部都係common sense🤷🏿‍♂️🤦🏿‍♂️
reviews.comment_grading:
Hmmm，黎到最controversial既一part，亦都係最多人不滿既一part。
TK sem頭已經講明呢科唔係淨係睇exam，仲會count class parti，至於個class parti係點count，syllabus寫到明上堂舉手答問題呢隻class parti係唔count的，你係course console比人既feedback既rating同埋你grp mate比你既rating係會影響你class parti同埋grp pj 呢兩個component既分數，rating好，呢兩個component就可以相對應咁調高，反之亦然，我諗TK都有解釋過佢會咁grade既原因係為左防止又人free ride，我諗呢個grading method相對mgmt2010已經好公平公正。至於狂小呢個course爛grade既同學可以反省下grp pj你貢獻左d咩/ course console你比左幾多句feedback😊
可以比翻d data大家參考：
Mid term: mean (28/34) 小弟: 踩mean
Project presentation: mean (9.2/10) 小弟: lowest
Final: mean (38.1/49) 小弟: above 0.6 sd
Lab final: mean (38.5/50) 小弟: above 0.9 sd
Feedback: high rating; peer evaluation: strong (好既會有email通知）
Turnout: A
reviews.comment_workload: Not too heavy. Just one group project presentation and final report.
